channel.title: 3 Variable Algebra
channel.description:
Once again, I need some help with Algebra :D
I understand some of it, but the other stuff I don't. So I'll give one problem to you guys, and if someone could go through the motions with me, that'd be great.
Thank you in advance, Adam
Here's one problem:
x-2y+z+8 2x+y-z=0 3x-6y+3z=24
Find ( X , Y , Z )
So I need to find the answers for ( x , y , z ).

item.title: 3 Variable Algebra
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Duh, surprised I didn’t see that Oh well.

Read full topic

Read full topic

item.title: 3 Variable Algebra
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I know this is old, but you didn’t really answer the question fully xxlegitxx. Certainly there are an infinite number of point solutions, but there’s only one linear solution.

First, the first equation given is weird…it could either refer to x - 2y + z = 8 or x - 2y + z + 8 = 0 => x - 2y + z = -8, but my guess is that it is the former. This does not affect the first step, which consists of finding the normal vectors of the planes:

x - 2y + z = 8
N = <1, -2, 1>

2x + y - z = 0
N = <2, 1, -1>

3x - 6y + 3z = 24
x - 2y + z = 8
N = <1, -2, 1>

Obviously, the first and third equations are equal (or at least parallel), and thus you are solving for not the point but line of intersection of equations 1 or 3 and 2.

You can find this line of intersection by taking the cross product of the normal vectors for equation 1 and equation 2 and then finding a point on the line of intersection (which boblinian did). Then use the vector/parametric form of a line to put the info together.

This may or may not have been what was required, but this a better way to do it imo

Read full topic

item.title: 3 Variable Algebra
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“boblonian, post:9, topic:152567”]X = 3
Y = 1
Z = 7[/quote]

Thats one solution. Only infinity more to list.

Read full topic

item.title: 3 Variable Algebra
item.dc:creator: @Unid_H4x0r Unid H4x0r
item.description:
@Unid_H4x0r wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:2, topic:152567”]To be honest, you won’t need to know how to do this in higher math. But anyway.

  1. Combine equations (adding, subtracting, multiplying, substituting), eliminating one variable at a time.
    Combine the first and second to get the equation: 3x - y = 8
    Combine the second and third to get the equation: 9x - 3y = 24
    Combine the first and third to get the equation: 0 = 0.

I assume combining the first and third is what messed you up. As you can see, the first equation is the same as the third. Therefore you can omit one with no hard feelings. So you have two planes in three dimensional space. They don’t intersect at one point, so there is no distinct answer. They intersect at one line, which by definition is an infinite number of points.[/quote]dame how much do you know?

Read full topic

item.title: 3 Variable Algebra
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

It can only be expressed in terms of of one of the planes. (x, 3x - 8, 5x - 8) is a answer.

Read full topic

item.title: 3 Variable Algebra
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

To be honest, you won’t need to know how to do this in higher math. But anyway.

  1. Combine equations (adding, subtracting, multiplying, substituting), eliminating one variable at a time.
    Combine the first and second to get the equation: 3x - y = 8
    Combine the second and third to get the equation: 9x - 3y = 24
    Combine the first and third to get the equation: 0 = 0.

I assume combining the first and third is what messed you up. As you can see, the first equation is the same as the third. Therefore you can omit one with no hard feelings. So you have two planes in three dimensional space. They don’t intersect at one point, so there is no distinct answer. They intersect at one line, which by definition is an infinite number of points.

Read full topic
